Ok, programming conditional logic 101 in a nutshell.
if statements require a true/false value to evaluate.
Your if statement ` if ( FindAttachmentBySlotName("weaponHandguardAK") == NULL )` reads in plain english "If the attachment at slot `weaponHandguardAK` is not null"

In order to know if the attachment at slot `weaponHandguardAK` exists, we "grab" that attachment with `FindAttachmentBySlotName("weaponHandguardAK")`.
`FindAttachmentBySlotName("weaponHandguardAK")` returns an object that either IS THE OBJECT you want or NULL (doesn't exist)

Knowing this, instead of just checking if the object is null, in my example, we first store the attachment in a variable THEN check if it is null like your code, then checks the item type as you requested.

Author: arkensor
Content: Hmmm I do use `EOnSimulate` but only on the client. And I use BuildingBase, and the object does have a physics body etc. I can not remember all conditions for it to become active and be simulated, but by default plain buildings are not part of the simulation cycle. You could go for `OnUpdate`. That is called right before the physics are calculated, so any collision change would be respected.

Author: arkensor
Content: MoveInTime works with buildings, no problem. Do note that for the host the interpolation does not happen. For your dedicated server it instantly teleports, there is no sweeping collision or anything. So do not move it too far per frame. Simulate the movement without it, e.g. lerp vector A -> B with fixed speed * deltaTime and then on top you can replace the setposition/settransform with MoveInTime(nextPos, deltaTime) to make it looks smoother on the client. For server it will remain a choppy e.g. 10 or 20 fps movement, but like that you get proper physics, and for the client its interpolated and looks butter smooth.

Author: arkensor
Content: During constructor objects are not initialized yet. The position and orientation are not final, and thus any vectors collected are irrelevant later on. Go for the EOnInit kind of events. There the object is a) created and b) is in the position it was "spawned" into correctly so it if safe to assume it will stay there unless modified through scripts or physics.
